main event: A series of spectacular luminous unidentified flying objects were reported over an area stretching from Connecticut to the coast of British Guiana, a distance of some 2700 miles. The objects were remarkably brilliant, seemed to have one or more leaders, discharged smaller objects, flew in formation, and maintained a substantially horizontal path.
interesting points: Witnesses reported seeing a luminous green globe, a flaming red, enormously long cigar-shaped object, and smaller offspring-shaped objects in different locations.
The objects were noiseless and flew at an incredible speed of more than 16,000 miles per hour.
Observations were made by numerous reliable witnesses from various locations, including seamen in the Caribbean area and observers in the Virgin Islands, Barbados, and Martinique.
The sightings spanned an area of about 2700 miles and lasted for approximately ten minutes.
The event occurred on April 14, 1958, and was later identified as the death of Sputnik II, the Russian satellite launched on November 3, 1957.
location: Connecticut to the coast of British Guiana
witnesses: Numerous reliable witnesses from various locations, including seamen in the Caribbean area and observers in the Virgin Islands, Barbados, and Martinique
